â11-20-2012 03:00 AM - edited â11-20-2012 03:05 AM

Unfortunately, step by step, this thread took a hostile turn, so the further responses, which added little to our understanding of the question raised, have been removed from public view.

 

Just about everyone involved contributed to their removal, but we all can do much better --everyone involved has also made important contributions to other topics here in the past and even today while this was going on.

 

To avoid re-creating these kinds of hostilities, let's follow these simple rules:

  • read what you have written before you post it 
  • don't ever hesitate to delete or edit instead if you can guess that someone might interpret your post as hostile
  • if you feel that someone else is stirring the pot, please do NOT respond in kind--report it to the moderators.

We aren't always there, but will deal with it at our first opportunity--and in the meantime it won't get any worse if the above rules are adhered to.

 

Thanks for your cooperation,

Forum Moderator 3

 

PS--If people want to discuss Shaq's initiative, or the role that weight plays in relation to diabetes,  please continue to do so, either here or under other topic headings...

â11-20-2012 12:39 PM

I feel that Shaq does not just focus on weight management as a tool to reduce the risk or control diabetes, he has other measures that he uses too.

 

He stated in this article:

"O'Neal says he limits the amount of carbohydrates in his diet, eats a salad for lunch everyday and only indulges in an occasional brownie, his vice. He also clocks one hour of cardiovascular activity each day."

 

Sounds like a good game plan to me.
